node.contents: There is a webservice client which uses ehcache in order to cache some results and avoid too many ws calls.

astNode.text: There is a webservice client which uses ehcache in order to cache some results and avoid too many ws calls.

node.contents: Apparently the server from where this ws client is called (on Weblogic OSB) just hangs and does not even write anything in logs ...just freeeze ! as soon as there is a little bit of traffic on it.

node.contents: The thread you highlighted is actually “available” to process a request so not the problem. Weblogic Oracle Service Bus relies on XQuery for XML manipulation. XQuery is known to be both CPU & memory intensive when used against big data payload.

astNode.text: The thread you highlighted is actually “available” to process a request so not the problem. Weblogic Oracle Service Bus relies on XQuery for XML manipulation. XQuery is known to be both CPU & memory intensive when used against big data payload.

node.contents: I just analyzed your Thread Dump. The thread dump is clearly showing a high CPU pattern where multiple threads are performing tasks such as parsing XML and attempting to allocate memory in some data structures such as ArrayList etc.

astNode.text: I just analyzed your Thread Dump. The thread dump is clearly showing a high CPU pattern where multiple threads are performing tasks such as parsing XML and attempting to allocate memory in some data structures such as ArrayList etc.

node.contents: I'm suspecting 2 possible scenarios at the source of the "hang" problem:

astNode.text: I'm suspecting 2 possible scenarios at the source of the "hang" problem:

node.contents: Excessive garbage collection & OldGen space depletion

astNode.text: Excessive garbage collection & OldGen space depletion

node.contents: The HotSpot JVM 1.6+ includes at the bottom Java Heap utilization. We can see that the OldGen space at 92%. This re-enforce the thread pattern that we see from the Thread Dump.

astNode.text: The HotSpot JVM 1.6+ includes at the bottom Java Heap utilization. We can see that the OldGen space at 92%. This re-enforce the thread pattern that we see from the Thread Dump.

node.contents: Culprit thread consuming your CPU and/or Java Heap memory

astNode.text: Culprit thread consuming your CPU and/or Java Heap memory

node.contents: In this scenario, one or a few threads may be involved in non-stop processing such as non returning XQuery etc. causing CPU surge & JVM contention.

astNode.text: In this scenario, one or a few threads may be involved in non-stop processing such as non returning XQuery etc. causing CPU surge & JVM contention.

node.contents: Now find below my recommendations:

astNode.text: Now find below my recommendations:

node.contents:
• Enable verbose:gc. This will allow you to perform a health & footprint assessment of the Java Heap along garbage collection frequency
  • Perform a CPU% per Thread analysis next time you see the problem. This will allow you to determine if you are dealing with specific Service Bus request(s) consuming your CPU and/or Java Heap memory

astNode.text:
• Enable verbose:gc. This will allow you to perform a health & footprint assessment of the Java Heap along garbage collection frequency
  • Perform a CPU% per Thread analysis next time you see the problem. This will allow you to determine if you are dealing with specific Service Bus request(s) consuming your CPU and/or Java Heap memory
